text: My name is Dustin Davau. I'm a senior

to creating performing metahumans in

useful for folks that are using
Metahuman moving forward.
So on the agenda today, we're going to
talk a little bit about Metahuman 5.6.
There's been a significant amount of
updates. We're going to go over some of

Then we're going to get into the actual

we're going to go into some performance

helping other folks like you who are
using Metahuman abroad.
So, the biggest change with Unreal 5.6
six is that we brought Metahuman Creator
inside of the engine and it's we've
taken all the good things that were in

application where you work.
It's a really exciting milestone overall

within the engine.
It makes it even easier to create a
metaum.
On top of that, we've grown the fidelity

ranging metahumans moving forward.
And every aspect's been updated.
So on top of that, because the database

more precision and control over aspects

and scaling along specific axes in the

And we're also super excited to announce
the parametric body system. Finally, you

a big feature that the Metahuman

So, what you're seeing here is the
parametric body system, and it comes

You can pin and unpin constraints so you

uh fixed body type option and you get

if you've used the expression editor,

On top of all of these things, all of

also added Metahuman for Maya and

Okay, so now we get into the
optimization set of metahuman. You've
decided that you want to use a
metahuman. How do we actually start
approaching the problem? So the first
thing that you want to do, we've built
in some stuff to metahuman 5.6 that
optimizes things automatically from
things that we've learned. And if
possible, we recommend updating the Maya
5.6. One of the key places that was an
optimization problem was the pose
drivers that were inside of the
animraph. The pose drivers in the
animraph were a significant cost and
we've baked them into rig logic in 5.6.
Rig logic is the node that runs a lot of
the animation features for facial
animation and body animation.
Previously, the pose drivers on a normal
like PS5 would cost about 1.4 4
milliseconds to animate per character.
But by moving them into rig logic, we've
reduced that cost down to4 milliseconds.
And this was an even bigger significant
change for switch users. It would take 8
and 12 milliseconds to run pose drivers
for one character, which is basically
untenable. And it's reduced that cost
down to that.4 milliseconds as well. And
that improvement in quality makes
Metahumans viable on a range of
platforms from high-end PCs all the way
down to switch.
On top of that, another performance
thing that we've done in 5.6 is we've
removed the Anom BP, the face Anom BP
specifically from the chain. And now
that opens up a few options for us
because on top of removing and just not
evaluating an anprint, it also allows
you to do things where you can layer in
facial animation through the
post-process blueprint. I'll talk about
that in just a second. And in general,
by removing the face anim, it was just
much more intuitive.
We've also made changes to the face
postprocess and BP with the goal here
being that we can simplify the overall
anim workflow and leave the postprocess
anp open for you to layer in animation.
We also have some alternative uh live
link usage. So there's a checkbox in the
live link where you can say use live
link or don't. And when you do this
inside of Metahuman Creator, it swaps
out the NMVP and allows you to connect
things without that all of that logic
that used to be in there automatically
default in the NMPP. So in 5.5 and
before you would have the Arcit logic
and the uh live link logic inside of the
NMVP, but now that stuff is removed to
remove that overhead
and those are now in their separate
NVPs. So if you want, you can also like
swap that if you would like, if you need
it.
So overall, the animation pipeline is
much more clean. It's much more linear.
You've got your driving animation for
your body, including potentially facial
animation curves from your uh captures
or your live link that play through the
body. Then you have your body
post-processing and BP where you handle
twist bones and other correctives. And
then you have your face post-processing
NMBP that handles layering facial
animation if you want.
And overall the other aspect to the face
post-processing NMPP is we have the head
movement IK. You can turn that off
entirely too. And that makes overall
things cheaper for you as you're getting
things prepared for game.
So, we know that there's improvements,

exported in 5.5 and 56? Typically,
metahuman comes with a couple different

the face, the body, and any clothing.
And if you've worked in any performance
or optimization land inside of Unreal,
you know that the more components that

cost. The other thing is that your
grooms are another components that you

all of these equate to a high fidelity
character but with multiple components
associated with them.
So when you're approaching performance
and optimization, you decide that you're
going to use metahuman. You've got 55 or
56 and you have these new features. You

If you're trying to build crowds, you

And you have to do a bit of work to do

And scalability is more than just loads.
So when you're thinking about

there's no magic button. There's gonna
be work once you create your metahuman

both old and the 5.6 update has the

uh metahuman. The goal here is to get a

The first thing that you want to know

profiling is that there's a couple key

up inside of profiles. The first one is
skeletal mesh components. Like I
mentioned before, all the metahumans
come with multiple components and
depending on the size of those skeletal
meshes, that can be very expensive.
Another area is animation evaluation and
that is because when we set up our
metahumans there are certain features
that you need to use in the animraph and
some of those features can be expensive.
Often times with skeleton meshes you're

So, a couple tips
in general. Uh, one of the things that

where you're going to be profiling. You

platform, definitely look to profile on

the code evaluation and and breakpoints

better accuracy on where specific calls
